subject: RE: [junit] Dependencies between test-methods
msgSnippet: Ilja, I think you were right. Currently, I m working on a simple parser and evaluator. In this example, I have lot s of tests to verify the parsers
messageBody:
Ilja, I think you were right.

Currently, I'm working on a simple parser and evaluator. In this example, I have lot's of tests to verify the parsers correctness. When I write the tests for the evaluator, I want to use the parser for setting up my fixture.
In this example, a failure of the parser causes the failure of the evaluator.

It would be nice to mark the evaluator-tests to depend on the parser-tests. A failure of the parser only causes the skipping of the evaluator-tests. This would ease the the search for the source.

If I try to reduce the complexity of a method, it usually only results in some private (and thereby untestable) methods.

Bye,
Stefan

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Ilja Preuss
Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2008 10:38 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Dependencies between test-methods


Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On Wed, Mar 12, 2008 at 12:52 AM, Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:
>
>> In my not so humble opinion, a complex method is a serious design smell
>
> For unit tests, yes. For integration/functional tests, it's pretty common.

Oh. I thought that Stefan was talking about a complex *production*
method that he wanted to test, not a complex test method.

Cheers, Ilja
